channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sala Fayyad, Palestinian Prime Minister, Resigns
item.description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad had clashed politically with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Western-backed Palestinian Authority, which governs the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank city of Ramallah in January.

item.title: Seeking China’s Help on Korea, Kerry Offers Concessions
item.description: Amid fears that North Korea is ready to launch a medium-range missile, the United States is trying to enlist China’s assistance in defusing tensions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry greeting China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, on Saturday in Beijing.

item.title: Hackers Reveal Witness Names in Hariri Murder Trial
item.description: Hackers plastered the names of the so-called secret witnesses in the murder trial in the death of the former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri on a major Lebanese news Web site.
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: A Push Against Tax Havens Gains Support in Europe
item.description: A crackdown against tax evasion could eventually extend to dividends, capital gains and royalties, significantly expanding the revenue earned by national treasuries.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Pope Francis Names Advisory Panel at Vatican
item.description: Vatican experts said the move was a strong sign that Francis was eager to consult widely and promote greater dialogue between the Vatican hierarchy and churches worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: Pope Francis with worshipers last week in St. Peter’s Square. His naming of advisers was seen as a move toward more collegial governance.

item.title: Syrian Forces Kill 12 Rebels in an Ambush
item.description: The government troops were trying to relieve a besieged military base in the country’s northwest.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russia Bars 18 Americans After Sanctions by U.S.
item.description: A day after the United States imposed sanctions, Moscow responded with a list of current and former American officials it is barring from Russia over harsh interrogation methods.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Mubarak, More Confident, Appears in Court in Cairo
item.description: Hosni Mubarak, Egypt’s former president, appeared to display new confidence in court, or perhaps a certain schadenfreude, as he appeared at a hearing to open his retrial.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Gamal Mubarak, left, with his father, Hosni Mubarak, Egypt's former president, in a cage inside the courtroom during the elder Mr. Mubarak's trial in Cairo on Saturday.

item.title: ‘Django’ Expected Back in Chinese Theaters
item.description: After being pulled on its first day of release, the film “Django Unchained” is likely to undergo slight cuts for the Chinese market.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: First Tastes of the 2012 Bordeaux
item.description: This is definitely a vintage to taste before buying. But tasting hundreds of reds in a day? Teeth stained, tongue hurting, you end up resembling a character in a teenage vampire movie, though you feel considerably older.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER
item.media:description: Opening week for 2012 wines in the hall of the Bordeaux stock exchange.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Assad Foes Hire Former British Diplomat to Plead Their Cause
item.description: Syria’s exiled opposition politicians are facing an uphill struggle to get firmer international help in winning the country’s civil war. They’ve taken on a New York-based adviser to help.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:credit: Filip Horvat for The New York Times

item.title: Kim Jong-un Tests Relations With China
item.description: Chinese news media openly discuss the souring alliance and some see Kim Jong-un’s youth as a factor in the less familiar relations with China’s leaders.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A delegation from China's Communist Party, led by Li Jianguo, a member of the Politburo, visited the Friendship Tower in the North Korean capital,Pyongyang, in November.

item.title: Plane Skids Into Water at Airport in Bali
item.description: A plane with 108 people onboard skidded off the runway on Saturday, cracked in half and landed in the sea while trying to land.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Indonesian Search and Rescue Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Rescue teams worked to get passengers out of a Lion Air plane after it slid off the runway into the water at an airport in Bali on Saturday.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 13
item.description: Sanctions against Russia; change for a Bordeaux mainstay; challenge for Mugabe foe; and Silicon Valley’s visa issue.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Olga Stepanova is one of several Russians barred from traveling to the United States.

item.title: 5 Dead and Scores Missing After Boat Sinks Off Indonesia
item.description: The passengers were apparently headed toward Australian territory when their boat broke apart in the water between Sumatra and the main island of Java.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: Avian Flu Virus Confirmed in Beijing for First Time
item.description: The virus has already killed 11 people in China, with 7 of those deaths reported in Shanghai, and the rest coming from three surrounding provinces.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: At Least 11 Killed Outside Mosque
item.description: A pair of bombs struck in quick succession outside a Sunni mosque north of Baghdad on Friday also wounded more than 30 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: 3 Sentenced for Role in Riots
item.description: The sentencing comes after an altercation led to anti-Muslim riots in which more than 40 people were killed in central Myanmar last month.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Former President Wulff Charged
item.description: German prosecutors charged former President Christian Wulff with corruption on Friday, more than a year after he quit amid accusations that he had accepted favors from business executives before becoming president.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Mending Ties With South Sudan
item.description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan visited South Sudan on Friday for the first time since the South broke away from Sudan in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, left, and President Salva Kiir of South Sudan discussed trading across borders.

item.title: Dismay Grows in Zimbabwe as Underdog Party Tastes Good Life
item.description: As long-awaited elections approach, faith is slipping in Morgan Tsvangirai’s Movement for Democratic Change, which now governs alongside President Robert Mugabe.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:credit: Pete Muller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zimbabweans headed to work and school in Harare. Voters are increasingly questioning the country’s erstwhile opposition group.

item.title: Park Geun-hye, Steely Leader of South Korea, Is Battle-Ready
item.description: As the crisis with North Korea escalates, critics and supporters alike wonder if President Park Geun-hye may have gone too far in presenting herself as an ultra-tough leader.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Park Geun-hye waved to crowds after her inauguration in Seoul in February, becoming the country’s first female president.

item.title: U.S. Puts Japan in Talks for Pacific Trade Deal
item.description: The possibility of including Japan in the regional agreement gave the deal heft, but it also brought complaints from carmakers in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bomb North Korea, Before It’s Too Late
item.description: North Korea’s Musudan missile threatens the security of America and its allies. President Obama should order a narrow, defensive strike before it’s launched.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JEREMI SURI
